awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EAGER: Developing tools to assess the evolutionary implications of partial clonality in alpine snow algae
awd_abstract_narration:
Many globally important processes like carbon cycling and human disease dynamics are a result of microscopic eukaryotes. Yet our understanding of evolutionary processes across the entire tree of life is limited due to the inherent challenges of studying microscopic taxa. Tools developed for macroscopic, and often obligately sexually reproducing, species are often not tractable in microbes where generation times are short, population sizes large, and extracting DNA from individual cells difficult. Further, population-level ecology and evolutionary biology research have focused on species that can be grown in the lab; yet, only ~1% of microbes can be cultured. This proposal focuses on the snow algae, a group of closely related, single-celled algae that turn seasonal snow packs pink or red. The aim is to develop novel single-cell population genetic protocols to study these threatened organisms and sentinels of environmental change. Thousands of cells from inter- and intra-annual Chlainomonas-dominated blooms in the Cascade Range of the United States will be genotyped. A goal is to understand how environmental factors (e.g., nitrogen) influence snow algal reproduction. The project will support two graduate students. The three PIs will integrate data into classroom-based and field-based curriculum for university-level students and share data with the public through social media and peer-reviewed publications.


This project uses snow algae to develop new methods for studying the population genetics of microbial eukaryotes from natural populations. The work will provide novel and critical techniques for studying reproductive modes that will be broadly applicable across microbial systems. Two novel elements are proposed: (1) combining single-cell isolation methods with state-of-the-art multilocus genotyping, and (2) using a novel microbial eukaryotic system (snow algae) with features making the method development tractable. Reproductive mode data will be generated and combined with measurements of (i) the ploidy of cells and (ii) environmental conditions to ascertain whether limited nitrogen initiates sexual reproduction. The approach is radically different compared to traditional microalgal population genetics that rely on lab-based cultures, raising questions of how representative those data are in nature. This proposal fits the EAGER funding mechanism as the single-cell population genetic methods are high risk-high payoff and should be readily transferable to other systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Most of the organisms responsible for globally important processes from carbon cycling to human disease are microscopic. Yet, across the tree of life, our understanding of evolutionary processes is limited due to the inherent challenges of studying microscopic taxa using tools and predictions that were developed in multicellular (and often obligately sexual) taxa. These tools are often not tractable in microorganisms where generation times are short, population sizes can be large, and extracting DNA from unique, individual cells is difficult. Further, population-level work on microorganisms has been done primarily on organisms that can be grown in the lab, but only ~1% of these organisms can be cultured. 

In this project, we used snow algae, microscopic, single-celled algae that turn seasonal snow packs red, pink, and orange to simultaneously develop novel single-cell population genetic protocols and study these microorganisms that are experiencing habitat loss due to climate change. We used our protocol to genotype cells from inter- and intra-annual Chlainomonas-dominated blooms in the Cascade Range of the US to link the prevailing reproductive mode to environmental factors (e.g., bioavailable sources of nitrogen) that influence snow algal blooms. 

We leveraged unique aspects of snow algal biology to facilitate protocol development, specifically that blooms are often composed of a single algal species, blooms can be easily seen on snow with the naked eye, and known consistency in the species that bloom. These attributes facilitated our development of population genetic protocols, but are not critical requirements for the transfer of this protocol to other systems. As long as cells can be sorted, our protocol will be applicable to marker development and, ultimately, genotyping in any microscopic organism. Our protocols will allow us and others to investigate evolutionary processes across the tree of life.

We characterized Chlainomonas diversity throughout bloom cycles, from late spring through the summer months, on a snow-on-lake habitat (Bagley Lake) in an alpine basin in the North Cascade Mountains of Washington, USA, in multiple years using amplicon and metagenomic sequencing. We used these data to develop methods to sequence longer length amplicons (using PacBio) better suited to distinguish snow algae taxa. These data were used to verify that the blooms on Bagley Lake are Chlainomonas-dominated and to examine if and how snow algae population structure varies seasonally (to facilitate development of population genetic tools). These data also contributed to the development of a hypothesized life cycle of a  potentially new Chlainomonas species, described based on linking field observations of cell morphologies to available habitat because no representatives from this species have been successfully grown in the lab. 

We were also interested in whether or not environmental conditions would impact snow algae composition, snow alga physiology, and ultimately their prevailing reproductive mode. In a recurrent Chlainomonas-dominated bloom on Bagley Lake, we found that community composition and life cycle were not related to bloom intensity or algal photophysiology over the course of a bloom. Based on amplicon sequencing data, the proportion of Chlainomonas was relatively consistent throughout the bloom while other members of the microbial community changed with changing environmental conditions.

Our results contribute to our understanding of the biology of Chlainomonas and its response to changing environmental conditions. We have also highlighted the utility of temporal field studies  in investigating life cycles of difficult to culture extremophile microorganisms and contributed new tools to assessing and understanding key taxa in ecosystems that are particularly susceptible to a warming climate. The project trained a number of undergraduate students. Results were disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, seminars, conference talks and through a number of public talks and inteviews inlcuding on Minnesota Public Radio. The materials and results were incorporated into undergraduate courses at all participating institutions.
